description: Early 17th century, borrowed from Middle French sabot (see French sabot below). Doublet of sabaton and ciabatta.

examples: She was a tiny little woman and wore big sabots and a big scoop.

entries.meaning: A carrier around a projectile in a firearm, cannon or other type of artillery piece that precisely holds the projectile within the barrel.

verbs.description: sabot (third-person singular simple present sabots, present participle saboting, simple past and past participle saboted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To enclose (a projectile) in a sabot.
